KING FOR A DAY. Act 1. Scene — CHORUS. Fishers gay let us sail away, Shines the sun bright to-day And the wind is fair, Softly sing by the shore And the waves from afar Will repeat our songs once more. (Enter Pifear). Pif Zephoris, Zephoris, where is Zephoris (to the Fishermen) Have you not seen him ? Omnes No, No ! Pif Oh Brahma, what bad luck. Omnes Why not fish without him ? Pif Without him it's quite impossible, Omnes Why ? Pif Because he couldn't fish without me Omnes What a funny thing. Tell us why, pray, tell us why. Pif Then listen : — SONG. Zephoris tho' he is the best of friends, A very bad fisher is he, But for me, all the luck that Brahma sends Would be lost again in the sea. As he keeps searching night and day For treasures and pearls which he never gets, And like a fool he throws away, Everything else that comes in his nets ; So while his fishing boat he empties, Why, I fill mine at my ease, So now you see why he cannot do withoutjme Zephoris is a handsome chap to see, But he lacks my dashing ways, The village beauties but for me Would surely laugh in his face, /&*&■

2 Oft have I seen the darling creatures, Look shy at him as if to say : Don't you admire my pretty features, But the big stupid turns away ; So if I were not by his side, Then all these sweet kisses would be lost, So now you see why he can't do witnout me Pif But who comes here ? It is Ziz 1. 'Tis the inspector of our coast, he is hard, cruel and unjust, and should he find us here he would surely make us suffer, come let's away. Zezel O stop there, stay my charming friends. Before you go to fish, I want to question you; everyone shall have his turn, so I'll begin with thee. Pif Pray tell me what I've done that you begin with me. Zizei. Each one shall come in turn so I begin with thee my g(od friend Pilear. Of a dreadful offence, my grief is quite intense, yuu're guilty I find. Nay don't answer mind. An offence made like this requires a slight fine. So pay or to jail you will go. Pif But if to ask I am permitted, What offence have I committed? Zezel It has not been committed yet, that may be so, But you will offend some day I know. So pay the fine, give me the bail, or if not come to jail, ; (to Zelide) 'Tis now your turn. Come here my pretty one. Zelide Ob, dear me ! Zizel Of a dreadful offence ; (enter Zephoris) Back, 1 say ; Omnes Zephoris ! Zephoris Old man, by my faith if crime enormous there be It is this shameful trade carried on by thee ; Zizel Imprudent, ignorant man, do you wish me to quarrel with you ? Zelide Pity sir ; pity my brother don't let me plead in vain I Zephoris My sister ! cease to implore him, Plead no longer ! Not on his mandate my safety depends, Our generous king, whose arm is stronger, Will ne'er injure the brother who his sister defends. Chorus and All — Cease to implore, &c. Zizel To prison he must go, carry him away ; Omnes To prison ? Zelide Hear me, kind sir, do not harm my brother, he quite forgot to whom he was speaking ; He didn't mean to insult you, he knows well what respect is your due ;

3 Zizel (to guards) release him a moment. Before I send prison, I will give you a moment to hear if you have any reason to make why to prison you should not go. Come look quick and give your reason plain (Zelide puts a piece of money in his hand) I almost relent now ( Zelide puts another piece of money in his hand). That is better (gives him another piece, to Zephoris). I now bear him no malice, your fault I pardon,' (to the fishermen). Now go to your work I permit you to fish, and my profits are good. Chorus — Fishers Gay, &c, Zephoris Stay Pifear, I wish to speak to you. Pif To me? Zephoris And also to you, my sister, (he takes their hands) Zelide What canst thou have to say to me ? Zephoris You cast down your eyes, you blush little sister, you know what I have to say to you ? Pif But I have not blushed ; I have not cast down my eyes ; I don't know what it is you have to tell us ? Zephoris Well, well, I will tell thee all my friend — There is a beautiful girl who is foolish enough to be in love with you ; Pif You call that foolish ? I think it is a matter of taste ; Zephoris However to me any weakness of heart is excusable, for does not my love overcome my reason so you have but to ask and I will give you her hand ? Pif Her hand, but what with it? Zephoris Ah ! you wish to know how much money we have ? Very well ask Zelide, for she holds the purse ; Pif Oh ! tell me Zelide how much is in it ? Zel (lowering her eyes) Nothing 1 We have Nothing ! Zeph Nothing Zelide ? But what has become of that left us by our father ? Zel Until now, I have kept silent, for fear of troubling you my brother, but to-day I do not wish to deceive anyone, and I will tell you the truth ; Zeph Speak ? Zel For a long time, dear brother, your fishing has been un- fortunate, and you have returned home so sad and down cast, that I could not reproach you, and I used piece by piece all the money that our father left us. Zeph Oh, pardon me, my sister ! pardon me ; Zel It is not your fault, if the fish don't come into your nets. Pif The fish ! Why if they come into'his nets he throws them out !

4 Zel Does he ? Pif He won't have anything to io with whiting, he despises the mullet, and throws the turbot back into the sea. Zel Can it be true ? Pif What he wants is coral, or a bank of lovely pearls, or — he is a fool in short ! Zel Enough, enough. Then brother she whom you love is rich ? Zeph I don't know. It was on a beautiful summer evening, and while wandering alone on this shore ; suddenly I heard a cry of despair, and saw a young girl drowing. I jumped off a high rock into the sea to help her, and soon, the poor girl was safely in my ar as. For a long time I struggled against the current which was running with great force, but at last I brought her safely to this spot, and on these sands I placed her. I gazed on her till the voices of her friends roused me from my ecstacy. Ashamed of my appearance, I ran away to hide myself for I wished to spare her all embarrassment. Zel And have you never seen her again ? Zeph Never. Whether she is of humble birth like you my sister, or whether she is noble, I don't know. SONG. I thought not of her birth and station When in the waves I saw her helpless lie ; Had she been the lowliest in the nation, My heart had answered that despairing cry. More as a vision she seemed to me, Fair as an angel she looked to be. We cannot ask the bright Aurora, When her soft light through the darkness drear has striven, If the golden rays she sends before her Come to her from earth or lrom heaven. Daily on the shore I sadly linger, Having no guide to find her but this ring, Which, on the sands, dropt from her finger. This to my heart does some comfort bring. Once more to see her, oh, heavenly bliss, In my fond bosom no thought bat this. Zel Alas, poor Zephoris, where will your love lead you? Zeph Oh, a hundred times I have tried to forget it, but could not. Day and night her image is ever before my eyes. Pif Shut your eyes then ! Zeph But my dream is over now. Fond hopes, away! I wish to regain that which my selfishness has made yon lose. In two months, I will have refunded all that our father left us. In two months you shall be united. Zel My dear good brother (embraces him). Pif My dear brother-in-law (embraces Zeph. awkwardly, Zeph, repulses him). Zeph Come let us go.

5 Pif I cannot leave I have to wait here for a customer. Zeph To whom you sell fish? Pif No, he is a lord for whom I carry letters, love-letters I suppose, for which he gives me two pieces of gold. Zeph Love or treason, who knows? Pif Treason. Zeph I distrust the honesty of this lord; however, it is your affair. Pif I see my customer coming, so good-bye, Farewell. (exit Zel and Zeph). (enter Kadoor.) Kad Thou art punctual! It is well, but remember to be silent. Pif I will my lord, mute as a fish. Kad Very good, for if thou speakest a word I will cut off your head. Pif (aside, trembling) Cut off my head! Ah, Zephoris said truly, this looks like treason. Kad If thou servest me with discretion I will pay generously, this letter will be the last and for this I will give thee three pieces of gold. Pif Three pieces of gold ! Zephoris deceived himself, he must be a lover. Kad Stay, thou wilt take it to-morrow, when thou goest with the other fishermen. Pif Certainly, then to-morrow the fair lady will have the letter, for it is for a fair lady ? Kad Thou hast guessed rightly, but not a word Pif Not a single word. exit. Pif. Kad All goes well. This fisherman is a fool. He has not the least suspicion of the important mission I have charged him with. Sleep on in luxury, insolent King, thy enemy waits. But whom have we h. re ? 'Tis the King and our beautiful cousin. They will suspect something. I must keep to the plan and muBt see all is right. (Kadoor keeps out of King's way). Chorus. — Glory to Brahma. He who protects us, He who directs us, In the skies so bright, Thou God of light, The stars are your own, And adore thy crown ; They show in your might, 0 God of light. Enter King ani Nemea. King Let us stay h,ere beside the shady tree, Now that we may breath in liberty — The air fresh from the sea. Nemea Here nature's grandeur doth our souls inspire ; All scenes like these I cannot but admire, Such pictures and such sights can never tire.

6 Kins Yes, what a glorious sight The sea in all its might, And all this is mine by right ; What do you say, my pretty cousin ? Nemea Oh, King your spirit is divine, You have too much humility ; The little bird whose melody We have just heard on branching tree, The brook that flows so rapidly, Each tiny isle set in the sea, Each pretty flower the sun uncloses, Magnolias, jessamines and roses, These delights our walk discloses, All for our King has great Brahma made them King Nay, you mistake, sweet lady fair, The rippling brook that shineth there, And when you look on scenes so rare, On smiling Isles the seas doth lave, Each pretty flower the sun uncloses, Magnolias, jessamines, and roses ; These delights our walk discloses ; 'Tis for their beauty great Brahma made them. Chorus. — Glory to Brahma, &c. King Ah, it is our good cousin ! I was surprised at not seeing you amidst the lords of our court. But the presence of Nemea reassures me, and I just said to her : " Princess, as thou art with me we shall not be long before we see the Prince Kadoor. Kad The flowers ever attract the bees ; Nemea And the wasps. Kad Princess, thou doest not like me, and perhaps it would'be wiser to renounce all idea of an alliance. Nemea I will tell thee frankly. Prince Kadoor, my heart I no longer possess. King Thou lovest another ? Kad And who is this man ? Nemea I don't know. Kad But, Princess — Nemea Listen, and thou shalt learn all. Some months ago I had a fancy for bathing at a place close by here. Suddenly an unknown current carried me away. I struggled, I screamed, and finally sank under the waves. When I came to myself I was lying on the sands. I asked my attendants who it was that savei me. They said, " We have seen no one ; you must have been rescued by a messenger from heaven, who has vanished on our approach. King . Kadoor, do you believe that Brahma sent a messenger ? Kad I, thy Majesty ? Nemea Oh, I don't believe that Brahma sent a messenger. My rescuer may have come from a boat I had seen at a distance.

7 Kad If that is the only obstacle, Princess, I will dare to pre- dict that he who keeps silent now, from motives of discretion, will remain silent, out of respect for us, when we are married. Nemea So be it. He will not make himself known ; but, if I discover him, I shall break with you. Kad Then, Princess, this is your decision ? Nemea Yes. If he who saved me comes to me and repeats to me the words I cried out in my despair when I was drowning, if his Majesty permits it, Iwiilgive him my heart and hand. King (with feigned severity) And if I don't, Princess ? Nemea Then, your Majesty, I will withdraw my hand King (laughing) I understand. Nemea Is that not the Royal yacht I see in the distance ? King Yes, Princess. Nemea If your majesty likes we will continue our walk, while we wait for the yacht. King Very well. Wilt thou accompany us, Kadoor '? Kad No, your majesty, I have some orders to give ; I will at the same time see tho royal rowers. King Your hand, Nemea. (As they are going off Zephoris and Pif. enter at back. Zeph. teeing Nemea utters a cry, and comes front as if in a dream.) Zeph Great heaven, it is she. Kad What does that fellow say ? Pif She whose life you saved ? Zi-:ph Ah, it is no illusion. Kad (to I 'if.) Get on to thy boat, fisherman, and on behalf of the King go on board that yacht thou seest yonder. Pif The King ? The King sends me on a message. Oh, my fortune is made. (exit Pif.) Zeph My lord, will you deign to say who that lady is so richly dressed, walking yonder ? Kad It is the Princess Nemea. Zeph A Princess ? Kad Why that question ? Zeph Pardon me, my lord, you could not understand (he icishes to el de him.) Kad {holding him back) Thou deceivest thyself, I understand thy emotion, and I know that you didst save the Princess when her life was in danger. Zeph Who has told you ? Kad The Princess herself. Zeph She ? Kad And is it true that thou didst save her ? Zeph Yes, my lord. Kad How long ago ? Zeph. It will be eight months to-morrow. Kad And when thou hadst rescued her from death where didst thon carry her ? Zeph I carried her here.

8 Kad Here ? But tell me the words she cried out when she thought herself lost. Zeph Ah, well do I remember them. She cried : " My mother, my mother, from heaven above protect me." Kad Marvellous 'tis thou, 'tis thou her life who saved, I will tell Nemea I have found thee and can tell thee she hopes thon wilt do as she wishes. Zeph Speak my lord, what does she wish ? Any desire of hers will be to me like an order from the king. What does she wish. Kad That thou shouldst promise, never to tell anyone, that it was the Princess thou didst save, also that thou promisest never to attempt to approach her, in short that thou never let anyone know that a common fisherman held her in his arms for one instant. Zeph Oh my dream, my beautiful dream. It has all passed now. Kad Dost thou consent to take this oath to me ? Zeph Say to her, my lord, that the Princess Nemea has nothing to fear from the poor fisherman Zephoris. Hear my solemn oath. I swear my lord to he silent for ever. Kad And never to approach her! Zeph (with an effort) and never to appoach her. I swear it by Brahma who hears me. Kad Very good (offers purse) I will tell her thou hast sworn and will add thou hast received thy reward. Zeph Yes my lord, I have received my reward, a thousand times more precious than this which I refuse. Kad What ? Zeph This lady so noble, and so haughty, I have held in my arms. Her proud heart has beaten against mine, and when I snatched her from the jaws of death, my lips have dared to press her forehead, tell her this, my lord, and she will under- stand that I have been well rewarded, and that I have no need of your gold. Exit Zeph. Kad He dares to brave me, so much the worse for him, but he will keep silent. He has sworn, and Nemea will yet be mine, but that man's oath is not enough, oh ! well he must be got rid of. The king and princess, now to enact my part (he seems to think deeply). Enter King and Nemea. King Still here ! Kad Your Majesty — pardon — 7. Nemea In what grave reflections were you plunged ? Kad I was dreaming prince of all you said to me just now, Nemea Aud you thought ? Kad I thought I hat he who saved jour life would be foolish to keep silence any longer.

9 Nemea You know him then ? Kad I know him. Nemea Oh ! tell me his name, I pray you. Kad Do you feel you could love him I Nemea I do indeed my lord. Kad Ah, well, he who risked his life for yours hoped you to love not to recognition. Nemea and King It is I to own Kad It is 1. Trio. Nemea 0 this news doth surprise me, Life he gave me, All happiness flies me, Oh why did he save me, Ah unhappy day. King 0 this news doth surprise me, My heart misgives me, This tale sorely tries me, What will he screen from me, Is it true? Did he save her ? Kad One word of mine has cui ed thee Of your pretended love, You dare not now dispise me, Thou art mine by heaven above, A hit I've made. Nemea "You understand, your word I am not doubting, But please say the day, the place, and tell me how life you saved. Kad Oh that is quite an easy task To tell you all you ask, T'was by that rock you see yonder, When near this spot I chanced to wander, And to that part of the shore, Your fainting form I safely bore, On the sands I laid your graceful form ; And lastly let me tell you, When to your aid I quickly did fly, You called aloud, and well I heard the cry, my Oh my mother from heaven above protect me, You know now it was true. Nemea and King T'is he. King What cousin do you propose to do, You must love him I suppose now. Nemea I have asked my heart, King and Kad Well ! Nemea Ah well my heart makes no reply, But you must wait a little time. King Well, I suppose you'll have your way, Your heart, your wishes wont obey. . It will not tell us any more, So princess come now all is o'er ;

10 Nem (to Kadoor) Since I owe you so much, My feelings I must smother ; For you indeed did save me, I'll wait no longer. Noble Lord as my scruples now are o'er, Yes I will give you my hand, But m5 heart retain ; Kad Retain for whom ? Nem Just for myself. King But time is master supreme Prince, Then take her hand her love will follow soon ; Now he who will take these small fingers, She will never forsake while his love lingers, When sweet words are said She will not resist him, But she will assist him. When they are wed. Kad At last 'twill be mine, That fairy hand of thine, It will belong to me, How happy shall I be ; Then when sweet words are said, She will resist me, But will assist me When we are wed ; Nem But when I am thine, My heart may incline To think only of thee, And when we are wed I should only love thee, But I fear instead Only friendship t'will be. King The Royal bark is ready (he takes Nemea' s hand) Kad I will see thee again soon my noble betrothed ; Nem (sighing) His betrothed, and I have promised him — Farewell my lord. Exit Nemea and King. Kad (not seeing Zephoris) We are betrothed, Nemea will never dis- discover the ruse I have employed. This fisher (he sees Zephoris). Is it he ! what does he do here ? Zeph (not seeing Kadoor) Why wert thou not of humble birth ? Why wert thou not a poor fisher-girl ? Kad What do I hear (claps Zephoris on the shoulder) Zeph My lord ! Kad Remember, thou hast promised to be silent, Zeph And I will keep my oath ; KAD(slstdtf) Now I can feel at peace the Princess is mine (he exits)

n SONG. She is a princess : Oh cruel destiny why art thou so bitter ? I only find her to loose her again, My hopes are blighted she is a princess, What would I give if I were king ? One glance of her bright eyes, My soul would free from paiD, If I were king. A willing slave I'd kneel, And daily bless my chain, If I were king. My proud and haughty rivals, Would sue to her in vain, If I were king. Princess or lowly maid, Within my heart should reign, If I were king. But to such sweetness I dare not lift my eyes, Her noble birth such a heart would despise ; Farewell bright angel, for ever lost to me, Alone I must die for ever lost lo thee. One glance of her bright eyes, &c. Zeph This sand was her couch for a short space, now it shall be mine (throws himself on sand). S\veet sand ; confident of my love, how many times hast thou listened to my raptures of her ? How many times 1 (he traces letters on the sand) but where are my thoughts wandering. What have I traced upon the sand ? Princess. She is a Princess. Ah ! If I were King, King, King. Chorus behind Scenes. Sailing swiftly on the ocean, With our barque so full of grace, Thou art like a sea bird in thy motion, On the wave you leave no trace. None can see thee, none can track thee Thou art like the fiying swallow ; Not a another baique can catch thee, Thou wilt lead but will not follow. Enter King and Nemea. King Now let us walk down this way, the path is so cool and shady. Well, my dear, why tremblest so ? Nemea (seeing Zephoris lying) Who can this be ?

12 King Surely it is some fisherman ? Yes A fisherman asleep, calmly he's sleeping, No thought or care has he, But what's this I see written on the sand 1 What a tale it is telling 1 I thought that he had not a care or thought, But hear you plainly see That I was quite mistaken, Read these words. I suppose before he slept, He traced here on the sand, Ah ! this is good, just read ! If I were King ; What would he do if he were King 1 Ah ! by my faith, a very pleasant notion Has come to me. Ho ! then my physican, This man sleeps, I wish him not to waken Till to-morrow, let him inhale your famed Narcotic, with which you have so oft wrought Sweet sleep to my eyes. Obey ; I have spoken ; i Nemea Profoundly now he sleeps. Nemea King King and Nemea Pray what comes next ? I'll repair the wrongs which fortune has done this [ grant his desire. It is his wish to be King, and King man, I shall A King for a day he "shall be, I will give him my kingdom ; We then shall see what he will do, Also how he will conduct himself, To the palace now quickly take him, CHORUS. Poor fisherman who would a crown be wearing ? Now for thy reign we are all preparing ; The king himself for thee is caring ; Gently then sleep and a watch we'll keep. END OF ACT I.

13 ACT 2. Zeph Where am I ? Can I believe my eyes, surely I am dreaming ; ob, heaven, where am I. CHORUS. 0 King thy people who adore thee, Hail the dawning of the day, 0 see them humbly bow before thee None thy wishes disobey. For thy wisdom shining highly And thy love which is its guide Will thy people govern rightly, Like the sun in all its pride. Zeph Ah, 'tis a dream which now enchants me, It is a vision of the night, But sing again ye charming beauties, Too soon shall I wake to the cold world again. 'Tis not a dream, I can see, I can walk. No, no I don't sleep, but these rich clothes I wear, this palace, (the King s lutes him, Zeph bows). King I trust your majesty has had happy dreams. Zeph My, my majesty, whom do jou think I am ? King I think thou art the KiDg. Zeph Who is the King ? King Thou irt, whose Primo Minister I am. Zeph My Prime Minister, ah, I was right when I said it was a dream. King Deign to remember thou hast been King for ten years, Zeph Ten years ? King It is true that, owing to a long and severe illness, your Majesty has been deprived of reason. Zeph I ? Kino Sometimes in your wanderings your majesty has imagined himself to be a poor fisherman named Zephoris. Zeph Yes, certainly. I am Zephoris ; that is my name.

14 King Alas ! the King has relapsed into madness. Oh, there ! the King's physicians. Zeph Physicians ? No, no ! they are useless. I am well, very well. I have a horror of physicians. King Then will your majesty take your morning repast ? Zeph (aside) A repast ; what an idea ; (aloud) yes, I wish to breakfast (the slaves bring plates of fruit and flagons of wine). Zeph One surely cannot dream and eat at the same time. I'll see if I am dreaming. Why yes, I'm eating, And now I can drink. I can eat. King Come pour out again the golden wine of Spam. Zeph Happy dream, brilliant vision, 'tis to you I owe this bright wine I drink, Or do they speak the truth, am I indeed the King ? King Yes, thou art indeed the King. Zeph Be silent, you shall not thus deceive me, I command at once you throw from the window the first traitor who dares call me king. See them now, they all seem struck dumb with fear. Surely now I must be dreaming, With wild thoughts my brain is teeming ; Yet my will they all obey, And trembling at each word I say. King Still he thinks tbat he is dreaming, Strangely yet to him 'tis seeming. Is he King or not, to-day ; Soon he'll exercise his sway. Zeph You are silent now. King I wish to prolong my days. Zeph How so ? King Why, I fear to go, my master, by the way of the window. Zeph To be thrown out of that window yon fear. Kino Yes, 'tis true ; 'tis not a thing my heart to cheer. Zeph Great Brahma ! pray my wits defend, And tell me when all this will end. King It will be fun you, may depend ; Let's hope we'll love this King I see. Then test your power, without delaying, Upon this slave which here you see. Zeph I'll put it to the proof. I'll see if in me lies this power supreme. Come hither, slave, come here, I say, Speak without fear, tremble not, but say Who am 1, speak out, answer me. Slave You are, indeed, our great master the King. (to minister throwing him out of window) Zeph Stay, I believe you ; come here, approach, poor trembling slave, to recompense the truth, I would I had the power to bestow some small gift. Gracious heaven ! in my pocket I hear a click ; come here, slave, take this ;

15 Why it is gold, and here is more. Surely now I must be dreaming, With wild thoughts my brain is teeming Yet my will they all obey, Tremble at each word I say. Great Brahma ! pray my wits defend, And tell me when all this will end. King Still he thinks, &c. Nemea O, King, deign to receive all the good wishes that my heart forms for you. Zeph 0, heaven, it is she I it is she ! Nemea Your majesty appears agitated. It is the first time I have been in your presence. Zeph No, no, it is not the first time (he takes her hand). Nemea (confused) But — Zeph Ob, d > not fly from me, stay here. Nemea Your majesty (to the King) my part is more embarrassing than I thought. King {stifling his laughter) Courage, you must conquer all that. Bring all your charms to bear on him. Nemea You wish it. Very well. SONG. I am afraid some dread fear your brain is besetting, No trouble can the future to you bring ; Your princely race are you forgetting, Come cousin, pray remember you are King. Of all the kings that reign in this fair land, Our Sovereign is by fortune favoured most ; Wit aod knowledge both come at his command, And we are blest that he should rule this coast. When all the world proclaims thy splendour, Let not thy brain more foolish thoughts engender. Say one word, a round of delights, Joys will fill all our days and nights. Yes, love, with her merry rites, at your wish will obey. Summer clouds are sailing high, We have many pleasures nigh. Why must we begin to sigh, or let sorrow stay, After the flower that blooms .o-day. Alas, quickly it may die. 0, meet not trouble half the way, alas, 'tis time enough. Zeph I listen to your words with rapture. I wish I could believe you, but, alas, I cannot, I feel that I am Zephoris, the fisherman, and this is a mirac'e. Nemea A miracle ?

16 ZtPH A dream (aside) yesterday when thinking of her, before I fell asleep on the sand, I wished that heaven would make me a king and now I am a King. Surely this must be a miracle of Brahma. Oh, it must be. (aloud) I believe I am King. King (laughing) He believes it. Nemea What happiness. Zeph. Yes, I believe it Nemea and if the future effaces all past things from my mind, there is one that will never leave me, and that is the memory of when I first saw thee. Nemea What are you saying ? .Zeph It was on this day. King The Prince Kadoor arrives. Zeph (aside) Kadoor ; ah, I remember, it's that man who made me take an oath. Nemea Go on with your speech. Zeph I cannot (aside) King or Fisherman I ought to keep my oath. Nemea What does he try to make me understand ! King Come now, pay your homage to the King. Kad (gaily) Your majesty, I come to announce the council (looking at Zeph) Heavens ! My fisher's here, near her ! Zeph Ah, you recognise me. King What is this ? take care. Zeph (to Kad) Well ? Kad (with constraint) Which of us does not know your majesty ? Ziiph He also — How is this, do you not remember me. Kad There is the council (ministers enter.) Zeph The council can wait. Kad Impossible, they say there are grave affairs to treat of. Come Princess ! Zeph But — Nemea Women you know cannot assist in State affairs. Zeph But I shall soon see you again. Prince Kadoor I wish to speak to you later, and mind you bring the Princess with you. Kad I — I (the king signs) Yes, yes, your majesty, (aside) I'll take care he sees her no more. King Does the king wish to take his place on the throne ? Zeph My throne ? Since Brahma has given it to me it is my duty to occupy it worthily. Nemea (aside) That was well said. King (laughing) Yes, the poor fellow takes his reign in earnest. Do not laugh Prince Kadoor, at this moment he is really the King. Kad So be it; come Princess. ( All exit except the Council, King and Zephoris).

17 King (to Zeph) The council is opened. Here is the report of your minister of justice. All the servants of the State fill worthily the offices your majesty has given them. Zeph That report is false. All How ? Zeph There is a magistrate of the name of Zizel, who sells justice. King Ah, we know nothing of that. ZErn Arrest him, and give him one hundred strokes of the bastinado on the soles of his feet, and furthermore deprive him of his post. King Very good (to sec.)
